items.title: Big City, Crazy Killer, Loner Cop
items.abstract: In Warren Ellis’s “Gun Machine” a murderous psychopath who believes he is a resident of pre-colonial Manhattan is tracked by a messy, isolated police detective.

items.title: A City Reminisces While Saying Goodbye, for Now, to Its Boardwalk
items.abstract: As elected officials in Long Beach, N.Y. promised to rebuild the 76-year-old Boardwalk that was damaged during Hurricane Sandy, residents gathered to share memories.

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: In Rural Minnesota, a 70-Acre Lab for Sustainable Living
items.abstract: Imagine a house that can go without heating for two days in a bitterly cold winter. Or a greenhouse with what may be the largest hot-air solar panel array in North America.

items.title: A Boutique for the Great Outdoors and the Urban Wild
items.abstract: Snow Peak, newly opened in Manhattan, is more than a camping store.

items.title: New York City
items.abstract: New books include Gerard Koeppel’s “City on a Grid: How New York Became New York.”
keywords: City on a Grid: How New York Became New York (Book)
Fun City: John Lindsay, Joe Namath, and How Sports Saved New York in the 1960s (Book)
The Con Men: Hustling in New York City (Book)

items.title: Big City Book Club to Discuss ‘We Are Not Ourselves’
items.abstract: After reviewing suggestions from readers, the Big City Book Club has selected the 2014 novel by Matthew Thomas about a multigenerational Irish-American family in New York.

items.title: Review: In ‘City of Thorns,’ Ben Rawlence Tells a Refugee Camp’s Story
items.abstract: In this book, Mr. Rawlence spotlights nine people to describe life in a Kenyan refugee camp he calls the biggest in the world.
keywords: City of Thorns: Nine Lives in the World's Largest Refugee Camp (Book)

items.title: De Blasio to Announce New System Dedicated to Addressing Gun Crime in New York City
items.abstract: Starting this month, people charged with the possession of a firearm in the city will be sent to State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, which will preside over gun arrest cases.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Bright Spot for N.Y.’s Struggling Schools: Pre-K
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s broader plan for public schools has been disappointing, but his universal pre-K initiative shows steady improvement.

items.title: Traffic Deaths in New York City Drop to 200, a Record Low
items.abstract: Fewer people were killed last year in vehicle crashes, a sign that Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Vision Zero plan is working. But pedestrian deaths increased.

items.title: As His Parting Gift, Urban Meyer Gives Ohio State a Rose Bowl Victory
items.abstract: The coach, who served a suspension earlier this season, had already announced his retirement, but he coached his team to a win over Washington in his final game.

items.title: The Army, in Need of Recruits, Turns Focus to Liberal-Leaning Cities
items.abstract: Too few recruits are signing up from cities like Chicago and Seattle, so the Army is trying to frame enlistment as a patriotic detour.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: A New Mayor and a New Relationship Between City Hall and Albany
items.abstract: Unlike their feuding predecessors, Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul appear to be getting along. They have their reasons.

items.title: They Had Reasons for Leaving the City. So Why Are Their Friends Mad?
items.abstract: When Covid hit, some New Yorkers abandoned the city for good. They left some angry friends.

items.title: In a Reversal, Kansas City’s Defense Plays Hero to Beat Broncos
items.abstract: Angling for the top seed in the A.F.C. with a win, Kansas City’s much maligned defense forced a fumble and returned it for a third-quarter touchdown.

items.title: When Production Design Plays a Supporting Role
items.abstract: The visual environments of “West Side Story,” “The Humans” and “Nightmare Alley” feel as alive as the actors.

items.title: Lemon Pepper Makes Everything Better — Especially Wings
items.abstract: Zesty, buttery lemon-pepper wings are Atlanta’s soul. But you can use the seasoning on just about anything.
